description.narrative: The Project development objective is to strengthen the capacity of the Judiciary and the Ministry of Interior and Justice (MIJ) to deliver timely, efficient, effective and quality dispute resolution services to citizens.

title.narrative: Judiciary establishes permanent user information offices to disseminate: standards of actblty., transparency, competency & effectvess. applicable to jstce. sctr.; & (ii) citizens# rights and duties

comment.narrative: The Project exceeded the initial target of 5 information offices and established 14 permanent offices in Barranquilla (2 offices),Bogotá (2 offices), Bucaramanga (2 offices), Cartagena (1 offices), Cali (3 offices) and Medellin (4 offices).

title.narrative: First national basic unmet justice needs carried out.

comment.narrative: Survey of needs.

actual.value: Achieved. Survey was carried out in 2013.

comment.narrative: First national basic unmet justice needs survey was completed and its results were disseminated in August 23, 2013.The surveywasapplied to 5,866 persons in 14 cities, with a trust level of 95% and error margin of 3%.

title.narrative: Backlog in the civil, family and labor courts of Barranquilla, Bogota, Bucaramanga, Cartagena, Cali and Medellin reduced by approximately 300,000 cases resolved or archived

comment.narrative: current backlog
# of cases resolved

The current inventory of the civil, family and labor courts in the six cities is of 547,963 cases, reducing the number of cases innearly 1,086,000. This important reduction was due to the measures promoted by the Project and the application of lapsing(perencion) and desist (desistimiento) tools of the new code.

target.value: Annual updates of the justice services map.

actual.value: Achieved. The map was updated annually.

comment.narrative: Justice Services Map has been updated. The map includes the justice service offer in the whole country, not only regardingjurisdictional offer but also alternative dispute resolution methods.The map has been updated five times and it allows users toidentify clearly where they should attend to solve its dispute, according to the controversy they are facing. In this sense, thishas been an important tool for potential justice services users that facilitates effective access to justice.Since itsimplementation, in December 17, 2013, until September 2014 the map had been consulted or used by 250.911 users.

title.narrative: A new administrative management model is adopted by EJRLB, including a new methodology for virtual training and applied legal research

comment.narrative: The administrative management model has been adopted by the EJRLB. Model was delivered to the Administrative Chamber of theSuperior Council of Judicature and was adopted by EJRLB in July 2013. The model started to fully operate the 14th of November, 2013.

title.narrative: New mechanisms and parameters are developed and approved by CSJ for the evaluation of the Judiciary#s staff under the management model, and staff is evaluated accordingly

actual.value: Achieved. Evaluation parameters and mechanisms was implemented and used to evaluate 1700 officers.

comment.narrative: The consultancy for the implementation of an evaluating mechanism has already been presented to the magistrates of theAdministrative Court. To date, 1700 officers have been evaluated. The project supported this process with the formula to carry outthe evaluation regarding productivity.

title.narrative: Decentralized units in Barranquilla, Bogota, Bucaramanga, Cali, Cartagena and Medellin provide services to 350,000 users.

comment.narrative: # of users

The decentralized units have already been adapted. The number of users attended was not measured. However, it is important tonotice that the decentralized units are available for the whole population in the particular locations where the centers are. Thepotential population in Barranquilla is 270,000 habitants, in Bogota 567,861, in Bucaramanga 350,000, in Cali 700,000, in Cartagena90,000,and in Medellin 1,500,000.

title.narrative: 3 specific training modules to support the management model are operational and benefit judicial staff

comment.narrative: The design and development of 3 training modules have been implemented and are operational. The design of the models wascontractedin 2012 and implemented in 2013. These modules were used in the whole country to train 354 trainers of trainers that mayreplicate this initiative in different regions of the country.

title.narrative: Management model operational in the 134 civil and family courts in Barranquilla, Bogota, Bucaramanga, Cartagena, Cali and Medellin.

comment.narrative: The management model had to be adapted to the new General Judicial Process Code. Up to date, the model has been implemented in allthe civil and family courts in Barranquilla, Bogotá, Bucaramanga, Cartagena, Cali and Medellin (380 courts). After the new codecameinto force, the model began being applied in all civil and family courts in the country. The work developed in the six initialcities will be useful for the whole country.

title.narrative: Management model operational in the 100 labor courts in Barranquilla, Bogota, Bucaramanga, Cartagena, Cali and Medellin.

comment.narrative: The management model had to be adapted to the new General Judicial Process Code. Up to date, the model has been implemented in allthe labor courts in Barranquilla, Bogotá, Bucaramanga, Cartagena, Cali and Medellin (102 courts). After the new code came intoforce, the model began being applied in all labor courts in the country. The work developed in the six initial cities will beuseful for the whole country.

title.narrative: 13 decentralized facilities are operational in Barranquilla, Bogota, Bucaramanga, Cali, Cartagena and Medellin.

comment.narrative: The refurbishing works have concluded, and the IT equipment and management models have been delivered. To date there are 14operational facilities (2 in Barranquilla, 2 in Bogotá, 2 in Bucaramanga, 1 in Cartagena, 3 in Cali and 4 in Medellin). The lastfacility began operating in June, 2014. All judges have been appointed to meet the needs.

title.narrative: 50 percent of the Judiciary staff in the civil, family and labor courts is trained and evaluated in accordance with the policies and processes developed under the project.

comment.narrative: The virtual training software for the design of the methodology for measuring the impact of training programs offered by the EJRLBhas been finalized. The new administrative model for the EJRLB and certification school and college is being adopted.To date 1700officers have been trained from a total of 1920. It is important to notice that all officers evaluated were trained as well.

title.narrative: Productivity in the civil, family and labor courts of Barranquilla, Bogota, Bucaramanga, Cartagena, Cali and Medellin increased by an average of 50 cases resolved per judge per year.

comment.narrative: # of cases resolved

The average number of cases resolved for the six cities included in the Project was 989. Except from Bogota (average 638 cases perjudge), the rest of the cities clearly exceeded the proposed target (Barranquilla 741 , Bucaramanga 813, Cali 1025, Cartagena 1205,and Medellin 1513)..

title.narrative: Crt. users of civil, family & labor courts of report increased satisfaction levels (up to 85 percent) in terms of the in terms of the quality, timeliness and effectiveness of services delivered.

comment.narrative: Survey was not carried out and therefore information was not gathered

title.narrative: Court users of the civil, family and labor courts in report increased satisfaction (up to 80 percent) in terms of accountability and transparency

comment.narrative: Survey was not carried out and therefore information was not gathered

title.narrative: 50 mediation centers certified under the new quality standards norm

target.value: 50 mediation centers certified under the new quality standards norm.

actual.value: 55 mediation centers have been certified under the new quality standards norm.

comment.narrative: 55 mediation centers have been certified, and the Project has also supported other 30 centers. The support to the other mediationcenters consisted of the presentation of good practices to improve performance in these centers.This additional support isimportantbecause the centers must be certified to officially operate and was an initial step to unify procedures, generating trustand equalattention in all centers.

title.narrative: Certified mediation centers provide services to 20,000 users

comment.narrative: The technical standard for quality and mediation centers has been completed and delivered by ICONTEC. To date around 165.000 usershave been attended.
